bestBHT.bht: The restoration of the divine image in Christ is far more glorious than what Adam had or could have had. Righteousness signifies a just relation within the soul and toward others, while holiness signifies the integrity of spiritual life and piety toward God. We are called to put on a completely new nature, a changed nature. In the new man, righteousness relates to our fellow men and holiness relates to God. This new man is created after the pattern of God, destined to be like Him in the end.

Henry Alford: The doctrine of the restoration to us of the divine image in Christ, as here implied, is not to be overlooked.
The image of God in Christ is a far more glorious thing than Adam ever had, or could have had.

Righteousness betokens a just relation among the powers of the soul within, and towards men and duties without. But holiness betokens the integrity of the spiritual life, and the piety towards God of which that is the condition.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: put on not merely a renovated nature, but a new, that is, altogether different nature, a changed nature.
God's image in which the first Adam was originally created, is restored, to us far more gloriously in the second Adam, the image of the invisible God.

holiness flowing from sincere following of 'the truth of God': opposed to 'the lusts of deceit'; 'righteousness' is in relation to our fellow men, the second table of the law; 'holiness,' in relation to God, the first table.
Albert Barnes: Learn, that regeneration is not a trifling change. It is not a mere change of relations, or of the outward condition. It is not merely being brought from the world into the church, and being baptized, though by the most holy hands; it is much more.
Man, by regeneration, is restored to the lost image of God.
The object of the work of redemption is to restore to man the lost image of God, or to bring him back to the condition in which he was before he fell.
Marvin Vincent: In righteousness and true holiness [εν δικιαιοσυνη και οσιοτητι της αληθειας] . Rev., correctly, in righteousness and holiness of truth.
John Calvin: Be renewed in the spirit, or, be renewed within or completely, — beginning with the mind, which appears to be the part most free from all taint of sin.
The regeneration of the godly is indeed — as we have formerly explained — nothing else than the formation anew of the image of God in them.
He warns us that both [righteousness and holiness] ought to be sincere; because we have to do with God, whom it is impossible to deceive.
Philip Schaff: The new man. ‘New,’ not ‘young,’ as in Colossians 3:10.
More than was lost in Adam has been given in Christ, but both creations are ‘after the image of God.’

'In' these, with these endowments or characteristics, the new man hath been created; the former points to moral rectitude, external and toward men; the latter, to the internal quality of spiritual life, its relation to God.
Archibald T. Robertson: Put on (ενδυσασθα). First aorist middle infinitive of ενδυω (-νω), for which see Colossians 3:10.
The new man (τον καινον ανθρωπον). 'The brand-new (see Ephesians 2:15) man,' though τον νεον in Colossians 3:10.
After God (κατα θεον). After the pattern God, the new birth, the new life in Christ, destined to be like God in the end (Romans 8:29).
John Gill: Though rather by the 'new man' is meant, the new nature, the new principle, or work of grace in the soul, elsewhere called a new creature; and it bears this name in opposition to, and distinction from the old man, or corruption of nature
Now to put on this new man, is not to make ourselves new creatures; for this is not by the power of man, but by the Spirit of God; this is God's work, and not man's"
For the new man is of such a nature, and so formed, as to tend to acts of righteousness and holiness, and to engage men to the performance of them
John Wesley: After — In the very image of God.

bhtAttempts.bht: We must not overlook the doctrine of the restoration of the divine image in Christ implied in this verse. The image of God in Christ is far more glorious than what Adam had or could have had. Righteousness signifies a just relation within the soul and toward others, while holiness signifies the integrity of spiritual life and piety toward God. We are called to put on not just a renovated nature, but a completely new nature, a changed nature. In the new man, righteousness relates to our fellow men and holiness relates to God. This new man is created after the pattern of God, destined to be like Him in the end.

We must not overlook the restoration of the divine image in Christ, far more glorious than what Adam had or could have had. Righteousness signifies a just relation within the soul and toward others, while holiness signifies the integrity of spiritual life and piety toward God. We are called to put on not just a renovated nature, but a completely new nature, a changed nature. In the new man, righteousness relates to our fellow men and holiness relates to God. This new man is created after the pattern of God, destined to be like Him in the end.

The restoration of the divine image in Christ is far more glorious than what Adam had or could have had. Righteousness signifies a just relation within the soul and toward others, while holiness signifies the integrity of spiritual life and piety toward God. We are called to put on a completely new nature, a changed nature. In the new man, righteousness relates to our fellow men and holiness relates to God. This new man is created after the pattern of God, destined to be like Him in the end.

The restoration of the divine image in Christ surpasses what Adam had or could have had. Righteousness shows a just relation within the soul and toward others, while holiness reflects the integrity of spiritual life and piety toward God. We are called to put on a completely new nature, distinct from the old man. In the new man, righteousness concerns our relations with others, while holiness pertains to our relationship with God. This new man is created after the pattern of God, destined to be like Him ultimately.

The restoration of the divine image in Christ is far more glorious than what Adam had or could have had. Righteousness signifies a just relation within the soul and toward others, while holiness reflects the integrity of spiritual life and piety toward God. We are called to put on a completely new nature, distinct from the old man. In the new man, righteousness concerns our relations with others, while holiness pertains to our relationship with God. This new man is created after the pattern of God, destined to be like Him ultimately.
